questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of low back pain and morning stiffness lasting 45 minutes. He reports buttock pain that alternates sides and notes that the pain improves with exercise. His vital signs are normal. Physical examination shows decreased spinal flexion and tenderness over both sacroiliac joints. Laboratory studies show elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), elevated C-reactive protein (CRP), and negative rheumatoid factor. What is the most appropriate management in the emergency department?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

HLA-B27 testing may support the diagnosis but is not necessary for initial management. This test does not change immediate treatment decisions and can be obtained in the outpatient setting.

B) INCORRECT:

Orthopedic surgery consultation is not indicated for inflammatory spondyloarthropathy. This condition requires medical rather than surgical management. Rheumatology is the appropriate specialty consultation and can be done in the outpatient setting.

C) INCORRECT:

Local corticosteroid injection is not the standard acute treatment for axial spondyloarthropathy. NSAIDs are the first-line therapy, with systemic treatments reserved for cases in which initial management is unsuccessful.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Inflammatory back pain with morning stiffness, sacroiliac joint involvement, and elevated inflammatory markers strongly suggest a seronegative spondyloarthropathy. These conditions characteristically respond well to NSAID therapy, which is the recommended first-line treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

While MRI may eventually be helpful for diagnosis, it is not an immediate priority in the emergency department. This patient's clinical presentation strongly suggests inflammatory spondyloarthropathy.
